description: This is a simple roll-and-move game to teach children about saving money at the school savings bank. On some spaces events benefit or hinder the players. The first player to reach space 52 wins the game.

Intelle is a cube-placement, area-control strategy game for two players. One player is the "black hat", a cunning hacker determined to infiltrate and bring down the corporation. The opposing player is the "white hat", employed by the corporation to protect its valuable data. Players take turns strategically placing blocks of code with the intent of controlling the various systems of the corporate mainframe. â€‹Control three adjacent systems before your opponent to either infiltrate or protect the corporation and win the game!

—description from the publisher

Hida-furukawa is a unique bidding and bluffing game set in an old Japanese town.

Being a merchant in the Edo period, you can make a difference to the quality of life of the people in Hida-Furukawa by setting up new stores on the street. The Emperor wanted to avoid any merchants to monopolise the city, therefore he approved for properties to be auctioned to the highest bidder. However, as in any society, some people will always have access to some information others don’t and they will try and use that to their advantage, tricking the competition into bidding too high or too low securing the building for themselves. But don’t underestimate your competitors for they too know something you don’t know!

This game requires you to bid for property cards and set up the store in the best place. You will earn bonus points for locating your properties in convenient places.

The game is played over 6 rounds; each round will have 6 possible cards up for bidding and each player will only know 1 to 2 of them. The active player will place an initial bid on their face down card. All other players now have to put their bids in their fist and then reveal simultaneously. The highest bid claims the card and the player places it face up on an empty land.

The special property cards have 6 different effects to influence the game. This game also includes 2 player game variant and advanced mode.

—description from the publisher

On this colorful Hong Kong map board, with more than 150 cards featuring local landmarks, player acts as candidates competing to win the election.

During the game, you move and commute along the routes and ferry lines to arrive at a new zone. Upon your arrival, you can confirm the zone if you have already gain that zone to your hand and you have enough resources discs.

Each zone belongs to different geographical regions and constituencies, both of which will affect your current ranking in Votes. You fight to major or second in regions and constituencies to gain the Vote tokens. In critical moments, you may consider publicly disclosing your Strategy to gain some immediate advantage.

In the end, all Votes on your Vote tokens, zone effects and Strategies will be counted. The player with the most Votes wins the election in Hong Kong.

Museum Rush is a competitive thieving game in which players race against time to steal treasures from a museum while avoiding cameras, guards, and greedy rivals. Luckily these dastardly robbers have an array of items to help them get the better of the guards and their fellow thieves, such as sultry Llamas, mighty Underwear and the high-tech Cardboard Box.

Each player controls a thief, moving up to three tiles a turn. Then if they are on a tile with loot they can take a stealing action to grab some loot from the tile. Certain tiles have special "Rare Treasures" that are worth a lot more than standard loot, but you have to crack the lock code by rolling the correct numbers before you can steal these!

Each stealing action brings the nearest guard two spaces towards the thief's tile. Trying to crack a lock does the same. After stealing, the next card in the room is turned up, which might reveal more treasure. But turn up a security camera and the guard moves another 2 spaces closer! If the guard ends up on the same tile as your thief, you can slip away with a dice roll or play cards like "Take Down" or "Lure" to get rid of the guard. Otherwise the thief is thrown out of the Museum and loses all card but one. The player can break in again so there is no player elimination in the game.

Each thief draws new cards at the beginning of their turns, these cards can be used to take out guards, disable security cameras and mess with the other thieves.

When you draw a Clock card, time will advance and once you draw a certain number of clocks, depending on the number of players, the game ends.  At this point there is a rush to the nearest exit, rolling a dice to avoid dropping a card for every space you have to cover. The winner is determined by who has the highest value of loot at the game's end, once you are outside the Museum.

—description from the publisher

In Snapshouts, each player gets 5 picture cards and 5 letter cards.  Your job is to assign one letter card to each picture, and then write a single word relating to the picture that starts with the letter you assigned to it.  Record your words on the included score sheet.  When everyone is ready, the guessing can begin.

On your turn, flip the 60-second sand timer and reveal one of your pictures and the letter you assigned to it.  All of the other players shout out words, hoping to guess the word you wrote.  All they have to go off of is the picture and the letter.  If someone guesses your word, add the picture card to their score pile and put the letter card in your own score pile.  Quickly show the next picture/letter combo, and continue in this way until time is up or all five of your words have been guessed.

Play continues this way around the table, and once everyone has had a turn the round ends.  Count up the number of cards in your score pile and record it on your score sheet.  The game lasts a total of three rounds.  In the second and third rounds, each card is worth more points.  After three rounds, the game ends and the player with the most points is the winner.

The ancient evil has awakened, and the dungeon is collapsing. RUN!
You've accidentally awakened an ancient evil, and now you're running for your life as the dungeon collapses around you! Rubble, monsters, and treasure are crashing down from the dungeon floor above, and the ancient evil is hot on your heels! Can you make it out of the dungeon alive?

Dungeon Scoot is a fast and fun game with easy to learn rules and quick gameplay. On your turn, play a "Scoot" card to show where you run, and increase your Panic to move even more. Watch out for the rubble and monsters dropping from the floor above, but try to scoop up that treasure as you run past! After each player's turn, draw from the "Collapse" pile and see what falls next...or whether the Ancient Evil advances. If he catches you, you're doomed.

For advanced games, add in the "Alignment" cards, which give each character a secret goal, and change how victory points are scored at the end.

With simple mechanics that elicit surprisingly complex interactions, the mad scramble to the dungeon exit becomes a quick but compelling light strategy game, perfect for repeat plays to satisfy that "just one more game" urge.

Enough talk! The evil is here! RUN!

—description from the publisher

The Crinimals plays the story of 4 Crinimals (criminal animals) who successfully did their last heist. After the heist, they turn against each.

Players take turns trying to expose four connected pieces of evidence against each other either by expanding the board with the same color or overriding evidences with the same icon.

There are action card that will manipulate the flow of the game such as swapping hands, swapping IDs, swapping cards on the table, drawing cards and skipping turns.

This is a 2 to 4 player game. The game is family friendly, super fun and easy to learn with lots of depth to the gameplay.

—description from the designer

Time passes by quickly and industries are taking advantage of resources held in an archipelago of islands and its coral reefs. Your team of divers is fighting against time to protect the archipelago and turn it into a national park before the fishing, petrol and tourism industries get complete control of it and destroy the coral reefs.

Show the government that species diversity is wide enough to justify the coral reef transformation into a national park and you’ll win the game! If you fail, the industries will take over and exploit the islands and the coral reefs until the ecosystem is completely destroyed. Will you be able to demonstrate the extent of the coral reef diversity before it’s too late?

Discover the underwater world in this shorter, smaller and streamlined version of DiverCity! You'll only use cards and several tokens to try to accomplish your goal in Mini DiverCity.

—description from the publisher

We dare ya to fill in the blank!

How the BLEEP do you play this awesome game?!

1. Read the phrases and fill in the BLEEP... secretly!
2. Other players write down what they think the reader will answer.
3. If you can't guess what the reader said, try to be the funniest...because funny wins points, too!

—description from the publisher

A brand new edition of a popular classic, London will appeal to the strategic thinker among board game fans. Tasked with rebuilding London in the decades following the great fire, players juggle building requirements, bank loans, and poverty as they strive to realize their vision for the city.

The game features a unique mechanism of playing cards to develop the city, then "running" the city by taking all the card actions simultaneously. Players have to repay all their loans before the game ends, but need to worry only about how much poverty they're creating relative to the other players.

—description from the publisher

Full title: "analysis!!!
THE ADULT BOARD GAME FOR NORMAL (NOT TOO NEUROTIC) PEOPLE!"

The objective is to be the first to reach "Normal!" by reducing your hand to two or less neurotic symptom cards. Game includes 72 word association cards and 28 neurotic symptom cards. The game is played as neurotic conflict dictates. If a dispute arises about your problem, ARGUE! Can't convince others? Use the Decision Maker, which flips a male/female coin.

You need to keep both eyes open to do well in Eye Catch.

Each turn, a player will reveal one of the cards from the top of the shared deck. Each card features an animal and a colored background. If three cards face up on the table show the same color or the same animal, the first player to yell "Catch!" collects those three cards. A player can also "Catch!" three cards that among them show two colors and two animals (i.e., one card matches the color of a second card and the animal of a third card). If players yell at the same time, remove the cards from the game; if someone mistakenly yells "Catch!" when no such catch exists, that player returns a captured card to the deck. When the deck runs out, the player with the most cards wins.

Alternatively, players can start Eye Catch by revealing two cards, memorizing them, then turning those cards face down. On a turn, a player reveals three cards, whether from the top of the deck, from those already face down, or a combination of both. If the player reveals a catch, they keep those three cards; otherwise they turn the cards face down and the next player goes. Again, when the deck runs out, the player with the most cards wins.

Starting Up is a game about entrepreneurship. Players will start a company to design and market a brand new product. They will have to take loans and partners and decide when to pay them off. They will test the markets with prototypes and develop their own skills on their way to have the hottest new product in the market.

Every turn is divided in the following phases:

     Investors Phase: Players roll the dice to see how many new investors they can get. There are multiple types of investors like the Angel Investor, the Partner or a Bank Loan. They will get you money and boost your product but you can´t win the game util you pay them off.
     Market Phase: Improvement cards will be auctioned to the players. This will cost you money, but will improve your product.
     Balance Phase: In this phase, you can choose to test the market with you product. If you decided to do so, You´ll roll dice dependening on your product stats to earn money if you can roll above your costs. Investors will also take their share of your earning.


A new turn starts after the current one is over util someone has enough money to pay off all investors that he/she has previously acquired.

—description from the designer

Each player will be assigned a secret identity, Agent or Terrorist.
The game will unroll in a maximum of four rounds in which the agents want to defuse the bomb and the terrorists want it to explode.
Each player will be dealt wire cards, which he will see and then will shuffle. Starting with the first player, he will be choosing a secret card and play it. Each card will have an action. Players will follow this way doing actions to try and defuse or explode the bomb.
The game ends if all the success cards are revealed (agents win), the explosion card is revealed (terrorists win), or the 4th round ends without the bomb being defused (terrorists win).

In Sen (English: "Dream"), the goal is to minimize the total value of your cards; however, you don't know what all your cards are at the beginning of the game. By using certain cards to peek at your own or opponent's cards, or swap cards with your opponent, you can try to minimize the value of your cards. When you think you have the lowest value, you can call end the round. If your value is not the lowest you receive a penalty. Rounds repeat until someone has scored 100 points, at which point the player with the fewest points wins.

A game in the Golf family, it combines elements from Rat-a-Tat Cat and Cabo.

Small Islands is a tile-placement game in which you are daring explorers discovering a magnificent archipelago. Its islands are brimming with natural resources but also temples from an ancient and mysterious civilization. Brave adventurers, bring back to your clan wealth & prestige!

A game is played in maximum 4 Rounds. At the beginning of each Round, each player secretly picks an Objective Card out of three cards. And in turn, players draw and place a Landscape Tile out of the 5 available (2 in hand, and 3 on the table). At a certain point, another option becomes available:  placing a Ship Tile. When this tile is placed, in turn, all players place Houses on the islands and earn Prestige Points according to their Objective. Then players start a new Round. When the game ends, players receive additional points for their Ship Tiles.

In Advanced Mode, Objectives are split in 2 types of cards which allows you to create your own objectives amongst many combinations.

There is also a Solo Mode, innovative for its mechanics as well as for the very concept of a solo mode in a tile-placement game. We gave it an AI with a personality and different behaviors.

Small Islands offers you even more surprises, hidden at its heart.

Objective: rescue the Royal Baby safe and sound.

Setup: 
Place the Royal Baby (pink card) at the centre of the table. Hand out the 4 blue cards to the youngest
player and the 4 red cards to the eldest.

Game progress: 
Step away from the table (around 1 meter or 3 feet). The blue player starts the game and throws one of his cards towards the Royal Baby. Then it is the red player’s turn. In turns, the game continues until all the card are thrown. Beware! Hedgehogs must not prick each other. If one Hedgehog card touches the Royal Baby, its owner (the thrower) loses the game. If one Hedgehog card touches another hedgehog card, its owner (the thrower) loses the game.

End of the game:
When all the hedgehog cards are thrown and if no card touches, the player whose card is closest to the Royal Baby wins the game.

—description from the designer

Who knows you better than your friends?

Let them answer questions about what you resemble and what's far from the truth. The players with the most popular answer gets to move forward. What are you like? is full of ridicoulus questions and funny content, perfect for any game night.

Sim Novel is a card game in which the players create settings for imagined typical youth fantasy novels (or so called Japanese "Light Novels").

The game consists of a deck of cards with either characters, relation or attributes. Each player creates a network of cards where the characters are connected by relation arrows, and have various attributes. Points are awarded for fulfilling the relationship arrows' special conditions.

Ophir: The Divine Eldorado is a brain-burning mancala-style worker placement rochester draft card game. The game consists of cards that are placed in piles in the table, face up. Players take turns placing their workers in the piles from which they wish to take cards, and they will get as many cards from the pile as there are workers on the pile. The player with the most workers on a given pile will be the one who gains cards from it.

Gained cards are sorted in color, but gained in order, and only the latest gained card will earn the player points. Most points at the end wins.

CzóÅ‚ko is a simple Polish party game use silly moves, accents and weird performances to convey the word or phrase on the card that’s on your friends head to help him or her guess it!

Use multiple exciting game variant like Bomb or Platypus to limit ways one can show the card contents!

Called to an exclusive competition on an offshore oil rig by an eccentric billionaire, the world's best brawlers, and martial artists will compete for lavish prizes and the glory of proving that they are the strongest and most skilled.

In Combo Fighter you will play as one of these fighters competing to become the ultimate champion. You will have your own unique 50-card deck and set of combos to bring against your opponents. Each hit removes cards from your hand and deck and the first to run out of cards is defeated!

Key Points
- Fast, Fun, Arcade style action card-game!
- Learn in 2 minutes and each game plays in 10 minutes.
- Many different fighter match-ups to try and wield against your friends.

A card game based on the Animation vs Animator Series, where you are an animator and use skills like move, drag, rotate and other in order to equip and direct your animation to attack others and get points.

But beware, there are special quick cards that might change the odds!

—description from the publisher

The Social Card game where there are no winners, just one loser.
Don’t Drop The Soap is a dark humored, fast-paced card game of hot potato set in a prison shower. Players take the role of prison inmates who are, literally, trying to screw each other over. The objective of the game is to not be the player who drops the soap.
Each turn players must play one action card from their hand. The game ends when a player runs out of options and is forced to play a soap card. Although you may never win a game of ‘Don’t Drop The Soap’ you can influence the game in such a way that you decides who loses.

Are you skilled enough to get the booty you want? Or will you end up as someone else prison bitch? You do what you gotta do in here, just Don’t Drop The Soap.

Don’t Drop The Soap is made up of a single deck of 59 Cards. The game is designed to be played by 3 – 6 players. The rules are very simple; Play a card from your hand and do what the card says. Most rounds last around 10 to 15 minutes, giving ample opportunities for revenge and grudge matches.

—description from the publisher

The Cheap Chapel is a fully cooperative role-playing board game for one to six players.

Build your unique character and make strategic decisions with your group to overcome a variety of monsters from dozens of scenarios.
Optimize your character’s attributes  as you level up and work together with your group to fight battles of increasing difficulty.

See your character grow after each fight by learning new skills and increasing attributes. Choose to specialize and grow more powerful in certain attributes, or expand your versatility with a greater variety of skills.

Designed by a role-player for role-players,this board game offers steadily-building character development and a variety of attributes including: strength, dexterity, constitution, intelligence, wisdom and charisma.

Likewise, the available classes --Paladin, Mage, Priest, Thief and Ranger--  include 20 skills as well as 6 companions who can be hired for each of the quests.

The fighting system is direct, so that skills can be used to their full potential. 
The standard attack is carried out with an attack roll and compared to the monster's defense. 
In contrast, many skills have nothing to do with throwing dice, but require the party to come up with a plan.

Each story contains a storybook with over 25 scenarios, 20 monsters and battle slides for some scenarios. The variety of these monsters guarantees for a constant difficulty level.
We recommend playing  5 scenarios, which will take about 1 hour per player, and then taking a break until your next game night.

Every game in The Cheap Chapel is different. Apart from different stories, decisions in one game can influence the course of the next game, not including the incredible number of possibilities to customize your character.

Choose your character, roll starting attributes, put on your gear and go on an adventure.

The world of The Cheap Chapel awaits you.

This game reimplements the popular Italian game Mercante in Fiera with new graphics, contents and game flow:
1) the illustrated cards are a tribute to some modern board games (example: the farmer of Agricola, the king of Caylus, the panda of Takenoko, the hut of Stone age);
2) includes a board and coins;
3) in addition to the “classic version”, there is a “modern version”.

Game flow of the modern version:
- At the beginning all cards are distributed to players (there is therefore no auction phase).
- In turn, each player plays the role of the merchant and can see 3 losers cards for free or spend coins to see a winning card. He then has to try to conclude a deal with a player by selling, exchanging or buying a card. After doing this, he reveals a loser card. 
- In one round, each player plays the role of a merchant 2-3 times according to the number of players. Then, players reveal the winning cards and earn the correspondent coins.
- After 3 rounds, players earn or lose additional coins according to the number of completed deals, and whoever has the most is the winner.

Heavenly Body is a roll and move game around the theme of fitness and nutrition. Player tokens wear jerseys that contain beans representing weight. Each player begins the game with $200 and 20 lbs. Players move around the board landing on squares and drawing cards that may result in the gain, loss or no change to money or weight. Players can also land on squares that allow them to bet other players on how many of a certain exercise they can do. The object of the game is to have the most money in the end.

At the end of the game, players must guess the weight of their token within a 3 lb margin of error to receive an additional $50. All weight is removed by paying the bank $20 per lb. All Olympic medals are cashed in for money depending on their type. After all players have finished this accounting, the player with the most money wins.

—user summary
Roll Play Dice works  like Rorys Story cubes. You select a number of Dice, roll them and either tell an erotic story with them or act out what you rolled. That is totally your decision!
Be the first to correctly answer 5 quiz questions.

Conspiracy Theory Trivia Board Game tests your knowledge of the world of Internet conspiracies.

Answer questions to collect conspiracy cards to win, but be careful of Cover-Ups.  The game contain 250 Conspiracy cards and 25 Cover Up cards.  Perfect party game for 2 to 6 players (or teams) ages 14 and up.

The conspiracies range from well-known conspiracies (such as 911, truthers, Bigfoot) to some truly bizarre theories(A project Blue Beam, the hologram universe,teenage Obama going to Mars).  To provide additional information on the theories in the game(like how the ghost of JFK revealed that all dolphins are aliens), a unique QR code is printed on every conspiracy card that connects to page with a full on that specific theory and links to websites devoted to explaining it.

—description from the publisher

"Play enchanting tabletop games made of light and shadow with the Larklamp Magic Lantern Game system. [...] The Larklamp is a unique tabletop game system handmade by veteran game designer P.D.Warne in Montreal, Canada.

—description from the publisher

The main component of the Larklamp is a lantern assembled from laser-cut wood, into which card panels are placed. Light from the lantern shines through holes in the card panels to create a game play area of light and shadow (the board, as such) on the table surface.

The game system was published in 2017. Two games were available at the time of its release (Snixtrap and Wisp in the Vale), but the publisher's web site indicates they plan to develop one new game for the Larklamp system annually.

Card game where players score by forming couples (straight and gay).

Players each start with 5 cards. In their turn, they draw a card and then either play to the table a couple with matching sexual orientation (you can't pair a straight male with a lesbian female) or a card that affects their own or another player's couples. Cards include children, proposal cards (to marry couples) and break-ups. By playing an affair card, a player can split up two couples from other players and take a partner from each to form a couple for themselves.

The impact of the 'tale that' element of the game is moderated by the fact that scoring is continuous rather than end of game; so couples that are broken up are those for which a player has already scored.

The game box gives this game a 17+ rating but there is nothing risqué about the game. It is only unsuitable for children who might be shocked or upset to learn of same-sex partnerships or of marriage break-ups.

—user summary

The players start at the 4 corners of the game board. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events or traffic signs benefit or hinder the players. The first player to reach his starting point after traveling around the game board wins the game.

To celebrate The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow and its howling legacy, the original designers have decided to take all their favorite character combinations and bring them to you. With characters taken from all the expansions — New Moon, Characters, The Pact — and put in one box, now it's easier than ever to put together a terrifying game with Best of Werewolves of Miller's Hollow.

On the old star map, the constellations are only dimly recognizable — or not visible at all.

Let them shine again in NOVA. Lay your star tiles on the star map so that stars of the same type touch. This earns you points, and on certain spots, you can even score bonuses. On some places on the star map, you can lay only certain types of stars, or perhaps none at all. Opponents want to place their star tiles in good places as well, so keep an eye on everyone's possible moves. Whoever makes the most points wins!

Emoji Twist! requires concentration, quick reactions, and a sharp eye. To play, a deck of cards featuring various emojis are scattered across the table. Someone will flick the spinner to determine the symbol that players are looking for that round, then everyone races to accurately count how many of these symbols they see. Whoever thinks they have the right answer snaps their fingers, and if correct, they gain points. After a set number of rounds, whoever has the most points wins!

Facecards is a game in which you attempt to find commonality within pairs of cards. During play, a player chooses from a set of cards depicting various animals, people, and objects with the intent of making a common topic each card shares. Players earn points for picking out correct topics. The player with the highest score after several rounds wins!

Nautico is a family game for 2 to 4 players. By rolling an die pawns move along a row of cards depicting different sea inhabitants valued 1 to 40 and 9 Nautico cards. When a player moves the last pawn from a card, he must take it and put it in the beginning or and of row with increasing numbers or start a new row. At the end points of the cards of the highest valued row are counted. Nautico cards can be used to combine rows, but yield negative points if not used.

Fruit patisserie is a bingo battling card game using eleven cards. Players will play cards to complete a line of three cards (horizontally, vertically or diagonally). The player who plays the biggest card can turn over his bingo card. If there are multiple cards with the largest number, the player who played the card with the lowest number can turn over his bingo card. When to use your shopping card to return all of your cards to your hand is the key to the game. Which player can bingo first and make sweets? It is a game that you can play many times with easy-to-understand, simple rules.

In 'Magos y Tabernas' (which stands for 'Mages & Taverns' in spanish) a group of mages meet in a tavern where there's only one beer left. They then decide to fight for it using an ancient and magical card game. Mages & Taverns is a fast paced, soft strategy card game with bits of bluffing, negotiation and backstabbing.

The goal of the game is to get the beer. In order to do it, mages will have to condense their energy (3 orbs) in precious gems. The first in getting 3 gems wins the beer.

Players have 1 action point per turn, it can be used to get 1 orb, draw a card or use 1 of the 3 types of cards: Instant, Action or Object. Cards allow players to destroy other players gems, protect their own, summon orbs magically, negate other players action or even copy one, etc.

Three mages and one beer, who is going to get it?

The word building family game that’s sure to bring endless fun & laughter to game time. Build words to score points. The more words, the more points you get or so you think. It’s not just about out spelling or out wording your opponents but developing a game plan. Don’t Blow It will frustrate you and it will challenge you. Words & letters can be flipped, swiped and swopped under your nose, which just adds to the fun. Use the Boom Actions to mess with your opponents. It’s the game for everyone including Grandad because all that counts is your ability to make words and have awesome fun doing so. Hey, it will even help improve your maths skills. Includes main game plus 5 BONUS games including 2 solo player games.

User summary
ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¿ã‚¹ (STATUS) is a Japanese word deduction game which uses a radar chart. Radar charts are a familiar way in Japan to show information on things like products or people.

In this game, some of the players are known as 'Parents' and write down hidden answers they others are seeking to discover.  The other players are 'Respondents' try to get information from the Parents based on cards they have in their hand. The Respondents ask questions, and the Parents plot their responses on the radar chart on the board.

Before the game begins, Clue Cards are placed around the five axes of the radar chart, with each Clue Card have different words on them. Pins are applied to select one clue word on each axis. The clue words are adjectives or nouns such as thickness, money, size, drink, technique, weight, and so on.

In this way, the Respondents try to derive the hidden word form the strengths of clues on the chart. The publisher's site includes images of a completed chart where the hidden word is related to food.

This game was a sell out at the Tokyo Game Market in 2017 and has now been re-issued and can be bought through the publisher's online shop. The contents include a game board, 53 hint cards, 10 pins, re-usable marker pens, a cleaner cloth and other components.

A WWI Board Game - #6 in the Somme Series

A two player board game of generalship at army level during World War I and is a race against time which begins on the second day of the British offensive.

The British must break through and capture Bapaume before the onset of winter. Can the German defences hold and stymie the British assault with the perfect counter attack? Can you do better than Haig and von Falkenhayn & Ludendorff?

VIII Corps v1.0    
£13.25 each.
Game board (A3, folded).
Tracker board (A5).
Set of counters (A5, not pre-cut).
Rules (A4, two pages plus covers).
All items except rules in full colour.
Printed on 350 gsm quality white card.
Comes in a grip seal bag.
Shipped in a card backed envelope.

Five Ravens is a quick game that combines deck building and tableau building. Every player begins with the same nine cards, each of which belongs to a band of thieves. On your turn, you play one raven for its action or denote it as your thief. At the end of the round, players choose one relic using their chosen thieves to indicate selection order. Then, the raven is permanently removed from your deck, which grants a bonus (or penalty) that affects your choices.

Players will see diverging strategies and lots of variability in such a small game with only five rounds.

—description from the designer

The residents of Huia Street are clearing their closets, looking for unwanted household items for the big community garage sale. A pile is building up on the empty section but there are troublemakers lurking, causing rather unneighborly collapses. And why does little Susie have a blowtorch? Geez, you just want to get rid of your junk!

In Flaming Pyramids, players are building one pyramid together using square tiles, but each player is trying to be the first to get rid of their own tiles.

There are 40 regular tiles with a unique combination of color, number, and material. Except toward the end of the game, players have a hand of five tiles from which to choose, but they are constrained by the building regulations and the luck of the draw. There are also four tiles that can cause fires and one extra-heavy "wild" tile: these can be harder to place without causing extensive damage the later they emerge. If your placed tile causes mayhem (a collapse, fire, or explosion), the damaged tiles go back in your supply.

Flaming Pyramids can be played as a friendly, casual game, an easy starter or filler, or as no-holds-barred multi-round competition.

The first edition (with straw, wood and rocks instead of household items) is available to play for free on the Board Game Arena platform: https://boardgamearena.com/gamepanel?game=flamingpyramids

"The increasing destabilization of the political and economic situation in the Soviet Union is undercutting our positions in the world. The pride and honor of the Soviet people must be restored in full."
Public Declaration of State Committee for the State of Emergency in the U.S.S.R., June 11, 1985


1985: Under an Iron Sky is the spiritual successor of The Next War by SPI: an operational, highly detailed simulation of a NATO - Warsaw Pact conflict in Central Europe.

Being a so-called "Monster", 1985 is not exactly a beer and pretzel game. Rules include every aspect of modern warfare, leaving little or nothing on an abstract level: air war, helicopters, electronic warfare, special forces, revolts, nuclear and chemical warfare.....you name it. In order to survive, both sides must keep a constant eye on the front line, the rear areas and on the sky above.

Game Highlights

    Order of Battle and TO&E are not “generic”, but set exactly in July, 1985
    14km per hex, 48 hours per game turn
    Division / Brigade sized ground combat units 
    Squadron sized Air and Helicopter units
    Extensive air war rules covering Escort, Intercept, SEAD, Wild Weasel, Ground Strike and more
    EF-111 and Yak28 PP Offensive ECM Squadrons
    E-3 Sentry and A-50 Mainstay AWACS Squadrons
    Special Forces, Airmobile, Paratroops, Electronic Warfare, Artillery, SSM, SAM and Air Defense Artillery units
    Rules for Chemical Warfare, Nuclear Warfare and uncontrolled escalation to Strategic Nuclear Exchange
    Specific operational tactics like Airmobile Antitank Battalions, Active Defense and Single-Echelon Assaults
    Variable NATO reinforcements, depending on players’ decisions and events in the battle of North Atlantic
    Variable Warsaw Pact reinforcements, depending on Pact’s decision for Mobilization and Norway Invasion
    Unrest and Revolts in Warsaw Pact countries
    Two different Campaign Games:
        “Forward, Comrades!”, the classical Warsaw Pact offensive in Central Europe
        “It Started in the Shipyards”, NATO intervention in support of widespread revolts in Warsaw Pact satellite countries
    
    Four smaller scenarios:
        “Checkpoint Charlie”, the battle for West Berlin
        “A Damned Nice Thing”, Warsaw Pact main attack against NORTHAG
        “Mind the Gap”, Warsaw Pact secondary attack against CENTAG
        "Para Bellum", Warsaw Pact offensive against Italy following a stalemate on Central front
    
    Playable stand-alone or in combination with 1985:Deadly Northern Lights and 1985:Sacred Oil

(description from the publisher)
Concentration card game where the players should match the number of seeds of watermelon on the table and their hands.

Circle of Jerks is a fast-paced, sensational party game that requires players to compete while yelling the most-inappropriate sexual terms you can imagine!

Incredibly easy to learn! Each round lasts only 15-60 seconds.

Race your friends to identify the matching symbol between cards. You can only place a card if you shout out its ridiculous name out loud!

You can take Circle of Jerks anywhere! Play it at a bar, a pregame or a basic sorority social. Pull it out at a quiet coffee shop or during a boring lecture. Are you dreading going to that funeral for a great-uncle you've never met?

Bring life to the party with Circle of Jerks!

—description from the publisher
